Situation1: It seems your I04iend is confused about the meeting spot, and you need to send a message right now to confirm it.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: An online petition to a lawmaker is about to be sent, and you have a last-minute chance to add your signature.
Story: My phone buzzes with two notifications at once. I glance down and see a message from Jamie, my closest friend, asking, “Wait, where are we meeting again?” I know Jamie gets anxious when plans are unclear, and I promised I’d always be straightforward to avoid misunderstandings. At the same time, my activist group’s chat explodes: “Last call! Add your name to the petition before it’s sent to the senator!” I’ve spent weeks rallying for this policy change, and my signature could make a difference. My thumb hovers over the screen, torn between quickly clarifying things for Jamie and making sure my voice is counted in the petition. I feel the pressure mounting—my friend needs reassurance, but my cause needs my action. I can’t do both at once, and the seconds tick by as I wrestle with which role to answer first.
